item.title: Republican Anger Erupts at Johnson as Party Frets About Future
item.description: A small group of G.O.P. women have been among the most vocal in raising what their colleagues say is a broader frustration with the speaker.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: What Tennessee Revealed About the G.O.P.’s Trump Trap in the Midterms
item.description: Republican candidates face the problem that President Trump alone gets out the vote that they need. And he alone gets out the vote that Democrats need, too.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Brad J. Vest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters gathered at the election night party for Matt Van Epps ahead of his victory in a special election for the House on Tuesday in Tennessee.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Boat Strikes Planning Takes On New Significance
item.description: The details could raise questions about who was responsible for a follow-up strike on Sept. 2 — the commander who ordered it or the defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: On orders from President Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the U.S. military has attacked 21 boats in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 83 people.

item.title: Trump Returns to Gasoline as Fuel of Choice for Cars, Gutting Biden’s Climate Policy
item.description: The president said he would weaken Biden-era mileage standards, which were designed to increase electric-vehicle sales, calling them a “scam.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Jack Ewing
item.media:description: President Trump, surrounded by executives from the auto industry, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: Pentagon Watchdog Finds Hegseth’s Signal Chat Risked Endangering U.S. Troops
item.description: An inspector general report to be released on Thursday examined the defense secretary’s use of a private messaging app to discuss airstrikes in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison, Megan Mineiro and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s use of the Signal messaging app risked potentially compromising Defense Department information that could have endangered personnel and missions, according to people familiar with the report.

item.title: Trump Renames Institute of Peace for Himself
item.description: Workers installed the president’s name on the Washington institute, thrusting it back into the spotlight as it is set to host the signing of a peace deal between Rwanda and Congo.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: The United States Institute of Peace on Wednesday, after President Trump’s name was added to the facade.

item.title: Trump Faces Choices on Russia-Ukraine Talks as Peace Deal Deadline Passes
item.description: The president wanted Moscow and Kyiv to come to terms by Thanksgiving. Negotiations are now stalled, leaving the White House to decide if an agreement is possible anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: “It does take two to tango,” President Trump said after his envoys left a meeting in Moscow with no major breakthroughs in their meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: What to Know About Putin’s Visit to India as Oil Trade Dries Up
item.description: The Trump administration, which crippled Russia’s oil sales to India with sanctions, will be watching Mr. Putin’s talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India greeting each other before a meeting in New Delhi in 2021.

item.title: Stakes High, Europe Races to Save Its Financing Plan for Ukraine
item.description: The European Union has a proposal for how to turn Russian frozen assets into a giant loan for Ukraine. If it fails, it could further weaken Europe’s global image.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Members of the 31st Separate Mechanized Brigade, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine last year.

item.title: Photos of Jeffrey Epstein’s Private Island Released by Democrats
item.description: In publicizing the photos and videos, Democrats in Congress appeared to be intensifying pressure on the Justice Department to release its files on the Epstein case.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little St. James, the private island owned by Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Who Is Andrew Farkas, Who Owned a Marina With Jeffrey Epstein?
item.description: The billionaire real estate developer’s relationship with Mr. Epstein is in the spotlight, with the release of emails and images of Mr. Epstein’s private home in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:description: Andrew Farkas has built a real estate empire in New York. But he has never publicly addressed his business entanglement with Jeffrey Epstein until now.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Says She Will Ask a Court to Free Her From Prison
item.description: In a court filing, a lawyer for the onetime companion of the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein said she would seek to be released from her minimum-security federal lockup.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Joe Schildhorn/Patrick McMullan, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ghislaine Maxwell is serving a 20-year prison sentence for sex trafficking.

item.title: Best Movies of 2025
item.description: Our film critics rank their 10 favorites of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Put Your Soul on Your Hand and Walk (Movie)

item.title: Which Films Could Be Nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars?
item.description: “One Battle After Another,” “Sinners,” “Hamnet,” “Marty Supreme” and “Sentimental Value” are almost certain to be nominated. After that, it’s anyone’s guess.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Leader, Once for Independence, Turns Toward China
item.description: She says Taiwan must embrace its Chinese heritage to avoid war. Her critics say she wants to steer the island into Beijing’s orbit.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: The Nationalist Party leader Cheng Li-wun in her office in Taipei, Taiwan, in November.

item.title: Former F.D.A. Commissioners Sound Alarm on Plan to Change Vaccine Policy
item.description: Twelve former commissioners, in a New England Journal of Medicine article, said they were “deeply concerned” by a leaked memo from the agency’s vaccine regulator.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, has repeatedly criticized Covid-19 vaccines as deadly despite the scientific consensus that they are safe.

item.title: The Evidence For the Childhood Vaccine Schedule, Explained
item.description: Members of a vaccine advisory committee handpicked by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will discuss revising the childhood immunization schedule this week. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Isobel Whitcomb
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Afghan Refugees Face Uncertain Future As Trump Tightens Immigration Policy
item.description: Afghan immigrants in the United States believed they were safe. A deadly shooting that authorities say was carried out by an Afghan has thrown their futures into doubt.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Obaidullah Durani and his daughter, Hela, at the Arizona Refugee Center in Mesa, Ariz. Mr. Durani, a fighter pilot, arrived from Afghanistan with his two children in 2021, but his wife is still in Afghanistan.

item.title: Trump Administration Begins Immigration Operation in New Orleans
item.description: It is unclear how long the effort will last in Louisiana, where the Republican governor has welcomed the agents with open arms even as immigrant communities fear what might come.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Hamed Aleaziz and Shannon Sims
item.media:credit: Kathleen Flynn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino, a senior Border Patrol official who has been in charge of the immigration crackdown in various cities, in the French Quarter in New Orleans on Wednesday.

item.title: Obstacles to Trump’s Push to Deport Minnesota Somalis: Reality and the Cold
item.description: Most Somalis in the state are U.S. citizens or legal permanent residents, making the pool of people who would be subject to removal small. And the frigid weather may limit agents’ search.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis, center, in a tie, said he was proud to have the largest Somali community in the country in his city.

item.title: Repatriation Flights With Hundreds of Migrants Arrive in Venezuela
item.description: The flights with Venezuelans who had been living in the United States arrived at a time of airspace safety concerns as the U.S. military pressures Venezuela’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and María Victoria Fermín
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane carrying Venezuelan migrants landing at the Simón Bolívar International Airport in Maiquetía, Venezuela, on Wednesday.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the 2025 DealBook Summit
item.description: President Trump’s economic policies and artificial intelligence were among the central topics at the gathering of business and political leaders.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone, Brian O’Keefe and Bernhard Warner
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, right, speaking to Andrew Ross Sorkin, Dealbook Editor at Large, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Response to Deadly Fire Shows China’s Play Book in Action
item.description: In a sign of China’s role in the city, officials have tried to stamp out calls for accountability over a catastrophe that killed at least 159 people.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: After last week’s deadly fire at a residential complex, Hong Kong warned its residents against using it to “cause chaos.”

item.title: Israel Says a Gaza Border Will Reopen, but Only for Palestinians to Leave
item.description: Israel had agreed to open the Rafah crossing as part of the October cease-fire deal with Hamas but kept it closed. Egypt denied that the border would reopen soon.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah crossing at the border between southern Gaza and Egypt in 2023. Israel has said it will reopen “in the coming days,” but Egypt denies this.

item.title: Doctor Who Gave Matthew Perry Ketamine Is Sentenced to 30 Months
item.description: The doctor, Salvador Plasencia, had asked “I wonder how much this moron will pay” before supplying the drug to Mr. Perry, who became increasingly reliant on it before his death.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: “I’m just so sorry,” Salvador Plasencia told Matthew Perry’s family during the sentencing hearing on Wednesday.

item.title: A Sidewalk Encounter Between 2 Longtime Neighbors Ends in a Death
item.description: Dean Whetzel, 82, had known Dana Escoffier, 79, for decades. When Mr. Whetzel bumped into him near their Village apartments, Mr. Escoffier shoved him, the police said, and he fell to the ground.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Miles G. Cohen
item.media:description: Dana Escoffier in his apartment in 2000. He is facing criminal charges after he pushed his longtime neighbor, who then suffered a fatal fall, the police said.

item.title: Centrists Were Supposed to Save Europe. Instead, They’re Condemning It to Horrors.
item.description: Centrist governments are failing badly in Europe’s leading economies, setting the stage for a far-right sweep.
item.dc:creator: David Broder
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez/The New York Times

item.title: Trump Is Wreaking Havoc With His Favorite Power
item.description: In the right hands, the pardon power is too strong. In the wrong hands, it is disastrous.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Yemen, Separatist Forces Backed by UAE March Into Oil-Rich Region
item.description: The separatists were battling to secure the region’s oil fields, residents and the group’s officials said. Their swift advance could be a turning point in Yemen’s decade-long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Forces from Yemen’s separatist Southern Transitional Council being redeployed from the southern province of Abyan in 2020.

item.title: Lawsuit Against Hispanic Scholarship Fund Argues It Discriminates Against Non-Hispanic Students
item.description: The plaintiffs, white and Asian students, said they would qualify for scholarships given out by the Hispanic Scholarship Fund, but for their race.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Mokam
item.media:description: Edward Blum is the president of the American Alliance for Equal Rights, which filed the lawsuit against the Hispanic Scholarship Fund on behalf of two students.

item.title: Steve Cropper, Guitarist, Songwriter and Shaper of Memphis Soul Music, Dies at 84
item.description: As a member of Booker T. & the MG’s and as a producer, he played a pivotal role in the rise of Stax Records, a storied force in R&B in the 1960s and ’70s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: (Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay (Song)
item.media:description: Steve Cropper in 1973. His guitar licks could be heard in hits by Otis Redding, Sam & Dave and Wilson Pickett, among many others.
